data.title: Apogee Enterprises announces CEO transition
data.description:
Apogee Enterprises (APOG) announced that independent chair Donald Nolan has been appointed as the company’s chief executive officer, effective October 31, 2025.

Nolan succeeds Ty R. Silberhorn, who departs from his role as chief executive officer and as a member of the board as of October 31, 2025. In connection with his appointment, Nolan will become executive chair of the board.

Board member Patricia Wagner has been appointed as the company’s independent lead director.

The board of directors will immediately begin the process of evaluating internal and external CEO succession candidates.

The company also reaffirmed its fiscal 2026 outlook for net sales of $1.39 billion to $1.42 billion (vs. $1.41B expected) and adjusted diluted EPS of $3.60 to $3.90 (vs. $3.72 expected).

Source: Press Release

data.title: Colgate-Palmolive Non-GAAP EPS of $0.91 beats by $0.02, revenue of $5.13B in-line
data.description:
• Colgate-Palmolive press release (CL): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of $0.91 beats by $0.02.
  • Revenue of $5.13B (+2.0% Y/Y) in-line.
  • Net sales increased 2.0%; Organic sales* increased 0.4%, including a 0.8% negative impact from lower private label pet sales having exited that non-strategic business
  • The Company’s leadership in manual toothbrushes continued with its global market share at 32.4% year to date

  • Based on current spot rates and including the estimated impact of tariffs announced and finalized as of October 29, 2025:

    • The Company still expects net sales to be up low single digits, including a flat to low-single-digit negative impact from foreign exchange.
    • The Company now expects organic sales growth to be 1% to 2%, roughly in line with year-to-date organic sales growth of 1.2%, versus at the low end of 2% to 4% previously. This includes an approximately 70 basis point impact from our exit from private label pet sales.
    • On a GAAP basis, the Company now expects gross profit margin to be roughly in line with year-to-date gross profit margin of 60.1% versus roughly flat previously, and still expects advertising to be roughly flat as a percentage of net sales and earnings per share to be up low single digits.
    • On a non-GAAP (Base Business) basis, the Company now expects gross profit margin to be roughly in line with year-to-date gross profit margin of 60.1% versus roughly flat previously, and still expects advertising to be roughly flat as a percentage of net sales and earnings per share to be up low single digits.

data.title: Xenia Hotels beats top-line and bottom-line estimates; updates FY25 outlook
data.description:
• Xenia Hotels press release (XHR): Q3 FFO of $0.23 beats by $0.01.
  • Revenue of $236.42M (-0.2% Y/Y) beats by $0.65M.
  • Net Loss: Net loss attributable to common stockholders was $13.7 million, or $0.14 per share
  • Adjusted EBITDAre: $42.2 million, decreased 4.6% compared to the third quarter of 2024.
  • Same-Property Occupancy: 66.3%, decreased 100 basis points compared to the third quarter of 2024
  • Same-Property ADR: $248.09, increased 1.6% compared to the third quarter of 2024
  • Same-Property RevPAR: $164.50, flat compared to the third quarter of 2024
  • Same-Property Total RevPAR: $289.76, increased 3.7% compared to the third quarter of 2024
  • Same-Property Hotel EBITDA: $47.0 million, increased 0.7% compared to the third quarter of 2024
  • Same-Property Hotel EBITDA Margin: 19.9%, decreased 60 basis points compared to the third quarter of 2024.

  • Current Full Year 2025 Outlook and Guidance

data.title: TDK Corporation GAAP EPS of ¥58.63, revenue of ¥1183.36B; updates FY outlook
data.description:
• TDK Corporation press release (TTDKY): 1H GAAP EPS of ¥58.63.
  • Revenue of ¥1183.36B (+8.6% Y/Y).

data.title: nVent Electric tops Q3 earnings; raises FY outlook
data.description:
• nVent Electric press release (NVT): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of $0.91 beats by $0.03.
  • Revenue of $1.05B (+34.3% Y/Y) beats by $40M.
  • Cash Flows from continuing operations of $272 million, up 72%; Free Cash Flow of $253 million, up 77%.
  • Raising full-year sales and EPS guidance: Reported sales growth to 27% to 28% (prior 19 to 21 percent) vs. estimated growth of 24.06% Y/Y; Organic sales growth to 10% to 11% Reported EPS to $2.57 to $2.59; Adjusted EPS to $3.31 to $3.33 (prior $2.98 to $3.08) vs. consensus of $3.30.

data.title: VCI Global to raise $5M at $1.80 per share
data.description:
• VCI Global (VCIG) entered into a definitive agreement with a single fundamental institutional investor for the issuance and sale of an aggregate of ~2.78M of its ordinary shares at an offering price of $1.80 per ordinary share, in a registered direct offering.
  • The closing of the offering is expected to occur on or about October 31, 2025.
  • The aggregate gross proceeds to the company from the offering are expected to be approximately $5M.
  • The company intends to use the net proceeds from this offering for working capital and general corporate purposes.
  • The VCIG stock price dropped 4.3% on Friday during pre-market hours of trading.

data.title: OneMain Holdings Non-GAAP EPS of $1.90 beats by $0.30, revenue of $1.24B in-line
data.description:
• OneMain Holdings press release (OMF): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of $1.90 beats by $0.30.
  • Revenue of $1.24B (+6.0% Y/Y) in-line.
  • 3 Q 2025 Managed receivables of $25.9 billion.
  • Raised quarterly dividend by 1% to $1.05 per share.
  • Board of Directors approves $1.0 billion share repurchase program.
  • The provision for finance receivable losses was $488 million in the third quarter of 2025, down $24 million compared to the prior year period.
  • During the third quarter of 2025, the allowance for finance receivable losses increased $60 million driven by growth in receivables.

data.title: Civeo Corporation GAAP EPS of -$0.04 misses by $0.08, revenue of $170.5M misses by $3.04M
data.description:
• Civeo Corporation press release (CVEO): Q3 GAAP EPS of -$0.04 misses by $0.08.
  • Revenue of $170.5M (-3.3% Y/Y) misses by $3.04M.

  • For the full year of 2025, Civeo is tightening its previously provided revenue and Adjusted EBITDA guidance ranges to $640 million to $655 million and $86 million to $91 million, respectively.

    The Company is maintaining its full year 2025 capital expenditure guidance range of $20 million to $25 million.

data.title: Valaris anticipates 90% drillship utilization by end of 2026 as backlog climbs to $4.5B
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Valaris Limited (VAL) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Anton Dibowitz, President and CEO, opened the call by emphasizing "another strong quarter of financial results with meaningful EBITDA and free cash flow generation." He highlighted the successful execution of Valaris' commercial strategy, including a contract for VALARIS DS-12 with BP Offshore Egypt, ensuring all four drillships with near-term availability are now booked for 2026.

  • Dibowitz explained that "demand for offshore drilling services is developing as we expected" and described a "robust pipeline of deepwater opportunities for our high-specification fleet," with advanced customer discussions underway for rigs completing contracts in the second half of 2026.

  • A key operational highlight was a fleet-wide revenue efficiency of 95% for Q3, supported by strong safety milestones across several rigs.

  • Matt Lyne, Senior VP & Chief Commercial Officer, noted that "since our second quarter call, we've secured new contracts and extensions, adding nearly $200 million to our contract backlog" and that the current total backlog stands at $4.5 billion. He detailed a $140 million contract for VALARIS DS-12 with BP offshore Egypt, expected to commence in mid-Q2 2026.

  • Christopher Weber, Senior VP & CFO, stated, "total revenues were $596 million compared to $615 million in the prior quarter, primarily due to fewer operating days for our floater fleet as drillships VALARIS DS-15 and DS-18 completed contracts midway through the third quarter without immediate follow-on work." He also reported "adjusted EBITDA was $163 million compared to $201 million in the prior quarter."

Outlook

  • Management expects Q4 total revenues in the range of $495 million to $515 million, down from $596 million in Q3, due to fewer operating days across the fleet. Q4 adjusted EBITDA is projected between $70 million and $90 million, with CapEx of $145 million to $165 million.

  • The midpoint of Q4 guidance implies "expected full year adjusted EBITDA of approximately $625 million, which is roughly $40 million above the midpoint of guidance we provided on our second quarter call" (CFO Weber).

  • Dibowitz reiterated confidence in industry recovery, stating, "we anticipate seventh-generation drillships will exit 2026 with utilization levels around 90%."

Financial Results

  • Q3 total revenues were $596 million, a decrease from the prior quarter, attributed to fewer operating days in the floater fleet. Adjusted EBITDA was $163 million, above the guidance range of $120 million to $140 million, driven by certain contracts running longer, higher ARO leased rig revenues, and lower support costs.

  • Adjusted free cash flow was $237 million, with $198 million in operating cash flow. The company repurchased $75 million of shares during the quarter. Cash and cash equivalents at quarter-end were $676 million.

  • CapEx for Q3 totaled $70 million, below guidance due to timing; the company expects full-year CapEx to be about $390 million.

Q&A

  • Scott Gruber, Citigroup: Asked about the appetite for further share repurchases. CFO Weber replied, "We executed the $75 million of repurchases in the quarter...we're going to be opportunistic, and that's what you saw this quarter."

  • Gruber asked about minimum cash needed for operations. Weber stated "around $200 million to run the business."

  • Gruber inquired about increased exploration activity. Dibowitz responded, "we do see an increase in exploration discussions...the consensus is that we're going to need additional developments in order to meet the world's energy needs."

  • Gregory Lewis, BTIG: Queried asset sales as part of shareholder returns. Dibowitz explained, "our capital return needs to be driven by delivering operational cash flow...the ability to sell assets when there are attractive opportunities, it is just opportunistic over and above that."

  • Eddie Kim, Barclays: Raised concerns about day rates for seventh-gen drillships. Dibowitz said, "we believe the market is playing out as we expected. I think that day rates for high-spec ships have largely troughed in the high 300s, kind of low to mid -400 range."

  • Doug Becker, Capital One: Asked about Petrobras discussions. Lyne stated, "Petrobras are looking across their entire value supply chain for potential savings in 2026...they want to maintain their production targets, which means they are likely to maintain a fleet of similar size over the long term."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for further details on share repurchases, asset sales, and contract day rate trends, expressing slightly cautious optimism but noting concerns about near-term cash flow and day rates.

  • Management maintained a confident and disciplined tone, emphasizing operational performance and commercial achievements, using phrases like "we remain committed" and "we expect."

  • Compared to last quarter, management’s tone remained confident, but analysts were slightly more pressing regarding shareholder returns and market recovery timing.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for full-year adjusted EBITDA increased by $40 million from the previous quarter’s midpoint.

  • Management now reports all four drillships with near-term availability are contracted for 2026, compared to three last quarter.

  • Total backlog decreased from $4.7 billion to $4.5 billion, while contract awards since last quarter totaled nearly $200 million.

  • Analysts continued to focus on shareholder returns, day rates, and contract coverage, with management reiterating discipline and operational strength.

  • Management’s sentiment remained confident, with a slightly more constructive tone on exploration and market recovery.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited "near-term commodity price uncertainty" but underscored a robust pipeline for deepwater opportunities.

  • Petrobras cost discussions introduce uncertainty for 2026, though management expects fleet size to remain stable.

  • Potential for some day rates to remain below $400,000, particularly in lower OpEx environments.

  • Analysts flagged concerns about gap-fill work for idle rigs and the risk of white space in the schedule.

Final Takeaway

Valaris management emphasized operational excellence, commercial execution, and disciplined cost management as the foundation for ongoing shareholder value creation. The company reported strong EBITDA and free cash flow, expanded contract coverage into 2026, and expressed confidence in robust deepwater demand, targeting high utilization for its drillship fleet by the end of 2026. Management reiterated a commitment to shareholder returns, driven primarily by operational cash flow and opportunistic asset sales, while monitoring market developments and maintaining financial flexibility.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
